    Add Details/summary block
  
#45055


talldan
  merged 53 commits into


  trunk

from

add/details-summary-block







Apr 6, 2023












          +487
        

          −3
        










      Conversation

      159





      Commits

      53





  Checks

  46





      Files changed

        25





 Conversation












 







    
            Copy link

 




Contributor






carolinan


      

      commented


        Oct 18, 2022

•




          edited
          
        






















What?
Adds a new <details> block that can be used to toggle the visibility of content.
Two inner blocks: Details Summary and Details Content.

The <summary>:  Uses richText. Its text defaults to "Details". Activating or clicking on this element is what expands and closes the content.
The content that is hidden and shown depending on if the details is open is inside a <div> below the <summary>. The <div> contains a placeholder paragraph.

 Closes 44539

Why?
One use case is to include text transcripts for video blocks, that are visually hidden until requested (toggled/opened).
How?
Some implementation notes:

The block is open / expanded by default in the editor.
The default behavior of opening and closing the details with click, Space end Enter keys is disabled in the editor.

Testing Instructions
In the block editor:

Create a new post or page.
Use either the block inserter or the shortcut /details  to add the block.
Select the Details Summary inner block and add your summary text.
Select the Details Content block and add a text in the paragraph or add new blocks.
Next, please test all the block settings:


Change styles of all 3 blocks. When changing the parent, but not the inner blocks, the inner blocks should inherit all the style options from the parent.
Change block alignment and width settings on the parent block (Details)
View the front of the website and confirm that the block settings are working and that the block looks correct.
A block that is closed in the editor should also be closed on the front.

Confirm that the details summary and details content are locked and can not be deleted or moved up or down, and that the block can not have multiple summaries or content blocks.
Please also test the global styles:

Open the Site Editor
Use either the block inserter or the shortcut /details  to add the block.
Open the Styles sidebar.
Locate and update the style settings on all 3 blocks.
Confirm that the style is correct in the Site Editor.
Save and view the front. Confirm that the style is correct.
Return to the block editor. Add a new details block and confirm that:


The newly added block uses the global styles
The previous block that you have styled uses its individual style, not the global styles.

Finally please reset the global styles in the Site Editor, and test styling the block with theme.json.
The styles added to theme.json should show correctly in the editors and the front.
Accessibility
Editing the block with they keyboard in the editor
Navigate to the block.
With the block selected, press down arrow to edit the text inside the <summary>
Press  down arrow again to select the details content "container" block.
Press  down arrow again to select the first block inside the details content.
Screen readers
Tested with Voiceover on Mac.
With the block selected in the block editor, Voiceover announces "Block details, document".
With the rich text in the summary selected, Voiceover announces:  "Add summary, edit text (text content), Insertion at end of text. Block details summary, document."
With the inner block below the summary selected, Voiceover announces the block name.
Screenshots or screencast 
The video shows adding inner blocks and styling the summary block:
https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7422055/222384524-36f8e74c-d03f-4b58-93d1-72b61b7f4c18.mp4

I'm not sure that View should be used in a block save function, as WordPress blocks always save HTML. In a React Native environment, View isn't an html element, so this might cause the block not to work in React Native (if it were supported).

        Mar 22, 2023










the block is already marked as experimental.

I'm referring to making it something a user has to opt into using the experiments page. If it's a toggle on the experiments page, it provides a bit more room for introducing breaking changes as there's a clear disclaimer on the page.
The same process has been used recently for quite a few features, and I think it works really well.
The experimental flag in the block.json is a little different. I think it prevents the block being shipped to WordPress core, and I'm not sure if it does more than that.

the separate blocks were used to enable the styling options.

Thanks for clarifying (and also to @fabiankaegy for the earlier clarification). I missed that discussion. I guess this problem isn't solvable any other way right now. Something like contentOnly locking could work well for this block if there were a way to still expose all the design tools. It's not something to worry about for the initial PR though, I'm just thinking aloud.

richtabor

        Mar 22, 2023

•




          edited
          
        

























On a separate note, is the decision on why this block uses separate 'Details Summary' and 'Details Content' inner blocks documented?


I feel like this is something that might make the block hard to use. Comparing it to the Quote block, that has inner blocks for the quote content, but the blockquote and cite elements aren't blocks. Similar might work well here where 'summary' isn't a block, but the content area accepts any inner block.

That's interesting. Would help alleviate the doubled-up block supports styling bits, as well as improve block selection. Currently you have to manually select the parent Details block to set it as opened for example.
I'm in favor of this; would simplify experience a good bit.

For experimental blocks, should the fixtures contain "name": "core/missing", ? Is that correct?
Or should the fixtures be removed?

Possibly the block won't be registered in the test, as window?.__experimentalEnableDetailsBlocks will be undefined.
You could try defining window.__experimentalEnableDetailsBlocks as true before the blocks are registered here:



gutenberg/test/integration/full-content/full-content.test.js


        Lines 66 to 71
      in
      ac2d3fe






 registerCoreBlocks(); 



 if ( process.env.IS_GUTENBERG_PLUGIN ) { 



 __experimentalRegisterExperimentalCoreBlocks( { 



 enableFSEBlocks: true, 



 } ); 



 } 





If that doesn't work, I think it'd be fine to remove the fixtures.

@talldan As far as I can tell from the comment chain and the code the reason for this is needing the various design tools we get via block supports individually for the different elements. This allows you to independently change the color / typography / spacing of the summary element and the content. Add a border around the entire element or just the summary etc.

I wouldn't consider that the primary/likely case, though it would still be possible to do most of this while also gaining the benefits of a simpler block experience. Here's a PR I put together to lean in that direction: #49808
